name: Lindsay Anderson
title: PhD
position:
Associate Professor,
Kathy Dwyer Marble and Curt Marble Faculty Director for Energy,
Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future
bio:
Lindsay Anderson is an Associate Professor in Biological and Environmental Engineering, and Systems Engineering, the Norman R. Scott Sesquicentennial Faculty Fellow, and the Kathy Dwyer Marble and Curt Marble Faculty Director for Energy at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future.

Prof. Anderson is enthusiastic about achieving a low-carbon energy future, and her research interests lie broadly in the use of systems approaches to enable high penetration of renewable resources through leveraging demand-side and distributed resources. The Anderson lab is diverse and energetic, and addresses many aspects of this vision through highly interdisciplinary research program that leverages operations, optimization, as well as environmental and systems engineering. If you are have good quantitative and computational skills, an interest in energy sustainability, and a willingness to explore new ideas, you might be a good fit with our group!

Prof. Anderson also holds field memberships (i.e. supervises Ph.D. students) in Civil and Environmental Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Systems Engineering at Cornell.

Before coming to Cornell, Anderson was an Assistant Professor in Civil and Environmental Engineering at the Western University in Canada. Dr. Anderson earned her Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics at Western and a B.S. and M.S. in Environmental Engineering at The University of Guelph (Canada).

name: Claire Guo
title: PhD
bio: Ge Claire Guo is a Postdoctoral Associate in Systems Engineering advised by Dr. Anderson at Cornell University. Claire received her Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering with a minor in Statistics at Iowa State University and M.S. in Industrial Engineering at Texas A&M University. Her research interests mainly lie in the use of stochastic risk-averse optimization techniques on the operations of electric power systemswith renewable energy resources.

name: Zongjie (Lisa) Wang
title: PhD
bio:
Zongjie Wang is a postdoctoral associate in Department of Biological and Environmental Engineering. Her research background encompasses optimal power flow; integration of renewable generation into power grids; active distribution networks and optimization techniques in power systems under uncertainties. Her current research is focused on economic dispatch problem in power systems with high proportional intermittent power sources (IPSs); characteristic optimal power flow towards a time period; quantitative characterization of IPS uncertainty models and designing the critical timescale of real-time power balancing under power systems with large scale IPSs.

Zongjie Wang is also a member of CEME in Cornell, she has been playing Yangqin (traditional Chinese instrument) since she was 3 and become a professional Yangqin player when she turned 8. She has been awarded gold medals over 20 times in international contests. She also organizes her solo concert in Cornell twice a year.

name: Vivienne Liu
title: MEng
bio: Vivienne Liu is a Ph.D student in Systems Engineering. Prior to joining Cornell, she got her Bachelor’s degree in Electrical and Information Engineering from Tianjin University and Master’s degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University. She is broadly interested in the area of control and optimization of smart grids with renewable energy integration and her current work focuses on using multi-objective simulation-based optimization methods to help inform policies on the management of microgrids energy systems.

name: Amandeep Gupta
title: MEng
bio: Amandeep was born in India where he completed his B.S. in Civil Engineering in 2010. He then moved to the United States to finish his M.Eng in Environmental and Systems Engineering from Cornell in 2012. Since fall 2012 he has been working in Professor Anderson’s group as a Ph.D. student.

name: Jialin Liu
title: BS
bio: Jailin received his bachelor degree with Honor in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the University of British Columbia in 2014. During his undergraduate, he did Co-op work at the State Grid Corporation of China, STT Enviro Corp and Best Cyclotron System Ltd.  For research, he is fascinated with optimization problems. His current research focus is the renewable energy integration into the power grid. As for hobbies, he enjoys playing cucurbit flute, traveling, workout and cooking.

name: Shikhar Prakash
title: BS
bio:
Shikhar Prakash is an M.Eng student in the Department of Biological & Environmental Engineering. Before joining Cornell, he worked as a Process Engineer for 2.5 years in India. Shikhar received his bachelor’s degree in Chemical Engineering from Jaypee University of Engineering & Technology, India in 2014. He is fascinated by research involving Optimization and Process Control. His focus of studies and research is towards optimization around renewable energy, data analysis, and machine learning. His current research is on the data center temperature control model and its demand response, and another one is predicting the marginal emission factor for cleaner energy.

In his free time, he enjoys cricket, swimming, badminton, cooking and reading articles.

name: Luke Sendelbach
title: Undergraduate
bio: Luke is a senior studying Biological Engineering at Cornell, focusing on computational biology, and is also beginning his MEng in the Anderson Lab. His coursework has led him towards computational modeling of biological and environmental systems. 36 Currently, he is working on predicting the periods of the highest electricity demand during the summer months in Texas as part of his work in the Anderson Lab. More broadly, he is interested in demand response as a tool to manage grid load during critical times.

name: Trisha Ray
title: Undergraduate
bio: Trisha Ray is a senior undergraduate student majoring in Electrical and Computer Engineering and minoring in Sustainable Energy Systems.  She is fascinated by the complexity of the power grid and hopes to pursue a career in the power industry.  She is interested using power flow analysis to understand how an increase in renewables will affect reliability.  She currently researching this problem on the New England grid system as a test case.
